image.altText: An Indigenous woman with curly hair outside speaking to camera, with a group of people behind her holding 'Vote Yes' posters

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will announce the date for the Voice to Parliament referendum in Adelaide this morning.

title.children: Assistant Indigenous minister says Voice referendum will be 'uphill battle', as date announcement looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By politcal reporter Jake Evans Former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull and Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek are not natural allies, heralding from different sides of the aisle. But the pair were shoulder-to-shoulder on the streets of Sydney this morning, ahead of the date for the referendum officially being announced. Mr Turnbull said referendums were "easy to beat", but that change would never be made without trying. "We’re all here encouraging our constituents, current and previous, to vote Yes, and by and large they have indicated they will, so that is very encouraging," he said. "This is a very important moment, and this is a time when we should bend the arc of history a little further in the direction of justice by voting yes." He was less enthusiastic as PM when in 2017 the Voice was proposed in the Uluru Statement from the Heart. He said his government rejected the idea then but now believed it was "winnable". "The Indigenous community have backed this issue in for six years. They have said this is what we want for recognition … and if we are talking about recognising Indigenous Australians in our constitution, we should be listening to the people who are to be recognised. "It’s not entirely consistent with my republican ideals, but it will work." Mr Turnbull added that it was "a pity" opposition leader Peter Dutton had not allowed a free vote for his Liberal colleagues like he did on same sex marriage and like John Howard did on the republic vote.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Turnbull and Plibersek hit the streets together for The Voice

children.content: By politcal reporter Jake Evans
Former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull and Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek are not natural allies, heralding from different sides of the aisle.
But the pair were shoulder-to-shoulder on the streets of Sydney this morning, ahead of the date for the referendum officially being announced.
Mr Turnbull said referendums were "easy to beat", but that change would never be made without trying.
"We’re all here encouraging our constituents, current and previous, to vote Yes, and by and large they have indicated they will, so that is very encouraging," he said.
"This is a very important moment, and this is a time when we should bend the arc of history a little further in the direction of justice by voting yes."
He was less enthusiastic as PM when in 2017 the Voice was proposed in the
Uluru Statement from the Heart.
He said his government rejected the idea then but now believed it was "winnable".

"The Indigenous community have backed this issue in for six years. They have said this is what we want for recognition … and if we are talking about recognising Indigenous Australians in our constitution, we should be listening to the people who are to be recognised.
"It’s not entirely consistent with my republican ideals, but it will work."

Mr Turnbull added that it was "a pity" opposition leader Peter Dutton had not allowed a free vote for his Liberal colleagues like he did on same sex marriage and like John Howard did on the republic vote.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yep, it's compulsory. The most common place to vote is at a polling place. Those locations haven't been published on the AEC website yet, but polling booths are usually set up at schools, churches, community halls and public buildings. They'll be open on voting day from 8am to 6pm local time. You must clearly write either 'yes' or 'no' on your ballot. For the referendum, postal votes will be allowed for similar reasons as those in an election — such as being more than 20 kilometres from a polling place, serious illness or being overseas. Pre-polling booths will be opened no sooner than 12 days before the official Saturday polling day. ABC election analyst Antony Green explains the voting rules in more detail here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do I vote in the referendum? And is it compulsory?

children.content: Yep, it's compulsory.

The most common place to vote is at a polling place. Those locations haven't been published on the AEC website yet, but polling booths are usually set up at schools, churches, community halls and public buildings.
They'll be open on voting day from 8am to 6pm local time.
You must clearly write either 'yes' or 'no' on your ballot.
For the referendum,
postal votes will be allowed for similar reasons as those in an election
such as being more than 20 kilometres from a polling place, serious illness or being overseas.
Pre-polling booths
will be opened no sooner than 12 days before the official Saturday polling day.
ABC election analyst Antony Green explains the voting rules in more detail here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians will be asked: A Proposed Law: To alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. Do you approve this proposed alteration? The permanent body would represent First Nations people and offer advice to government on policies and laws that impact the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Here's how the PM first announced the wording, and some thoughts from the ABC's Fran Kelly on the history of constitutional recognition in Australia:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's the wording of the referendum question?

props.alt: An Indigenous mural painted on a corrugated iron wall

children.content: (ABC News: Che Chorley)
Australians will be asked:
A Proposed Law: To alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.
Do you approve this proposed alteration?
The permanent body would represent First Nations people and offer advice to government on policies and laws that impact the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
Here's how the PM first announced the wording, and some thoughts from the ABC's Fran Kelly on the history of constitutional recognition in Australia:

image.altText: A picture of a smiling man's face, attached to a wooden cross outside.

items.synopsis: At the Krasnopilske military cemetery in eastern Ukraine, one of the first things you hear is weeping — the women here all know each other, but they're bound together for devastating reasons.

title.children: Ukraine doesn't release its number of war casualties — at this cemetery, the real toll is on show

image.altText: A composite image of five women, all smiling, with a soft green background.

items.synopsis: In any given year, at least 1 million Australian children and adults are living with an eating disorder. Four women have shared their experiences and hopes for a new road map on eating disorders.

title.children: 'Why don't I look like that'? Women share heartbreaking stories of life with an eating disorder

image.altText: A woman with short dark hair stares at her reflection in a mirror, without smiling.

items.synopsis: Australia now has a 10-year road map on eating disorders. Here’s a look at what it includes.

title.children: What's in the National Eating Disorders Strategy?

image.altText: A man looks on.

items.synopsis: When Luis Rubiales grabbed Jenni Hermoso's face and kissed her on the lips during post-match celebrations at Stadium Australia, Spaniards were forced to pick a side, and start a national conversation about chauvinism.

title.children: 'Something deeply rotten': Soccer, chauvinism and the national conversation Spain had to have

image.altText: Flowers grave Wagner Yevgeny Prigozhin after funeral

items.synopsis: A Kremlin spokesperson said funeral plans for the Wagner chief who died in a plane crash last week were up to relatives.

title.children: Mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin buried on outskirts of St Petersburg

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and glasses stares out the window while grasping a cup of tea.

items.synopsis: Analysis of Federal Court data has found 10 per cent of all forced bankruptcies across Australia are from strata levy debts.

title.children: Nicki owns a flat, but has gone into debt due to strata fees

image.altText: Archival image, wide-shot, of trees, beach and water on Banaba island, Kiribati.

items.synopsis: People from the remote Pacific Island of Banaba say they've been blindsided over an agreement to explore phosphate mining on the tiny atoll and Centrex, an Australian mining company, inked the exploration deal.

title.children: Mining forced most of Banaba's population to relocate. Now an Australian company plans to mine the island

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Investigation says Tesla's autopilot could lead to driver 'failure', Burger King faces too small burger lawsuit. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The former head of the competition regulator says the federal government's decision to block additional Qatar Airways flights in Australia is designed to look after Qantas. Last month, the government rejected an application to add 21 extra flights per week because it's not in the national interest. This week, Qantas boss Alan Joyce told a Senate committee that more flights from the Middle Eastern carrier would distort the market. But, former ACCC chair Allan Fels says the extra flights would help bring down prices. "Customers are being put second, so is tourism, business, freight, many other interests — also other airlines," he says. "So there's no secret reason for it — it's just looking after Qantas."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former ACCC chair says 'customers are being put second' by decision to block additional flights

children.content: The former head of the competition regulator says the federal government's decision to block additional Qatar Airways flights in Australia is designed to look after Qantas.
Last month, the government rejected an application to add 21 extra flights per week because it's not in the national interest.
This week, Qantas boss Alan Joyce told a Senate committee that more flights
from the Middle Eastern carrier would distort the market.
But, former ACCC chair Allan Fels says the extra flights would help bring down prices.
"Customers are being put second, so is tourism, business, freight, many other interests — also other airlines," he says.
"So there's no secret reason for it — it's just looking after Qantas."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: England will roll out a world-first seven-minute cancer treatment jab. The current method of an intravenous infusion takes up to an hour. Britain's state-run National Health Service says the move will free up more time for cancer teams. NHS England says it expects the majority of some 3,500 patients starting the treatment every year to switch to the time-saving jab.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: World-first cancer treatment in UK

children.content: England will roll out a world-first seven-minute cancer treatment jab.
The current method of an intravenous infusion takes up to an hour.
Britain's state-run National Health Service says the move will free up more time for cancer teams.
NHS England says it expects the majority of some 3,500 patients starting the treatment every year to switch to the time-saving jab.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US, late-night television hosts are launching a new podcast to chat about Hollywood's ongoing labor disputes and raise funds for their striking staff writers. Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon, Jimmy Kimmel, Seth Meyers and John Oliver will take part in the podcast that debuts on Wednesday called Strike Force Five. Members of the Writers Guild of America went on strike in May and the SAG-AFTRA actors union walked off the job in July. Without teams of writers to pen topical jokes, the late-night shows have been airing re-runs for nearly four months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US TV hosts launch podcasts to raise funds for striking writers

children.content: Jimmy Fallon.
(Reuters: Evelyn Hockstein)
In the US, late-night television hosts are launching a new podcast to chat about Hollywood's ongoing labor disputes and raise funds for their striking staff writers.
Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon, Jimmy Kimmel, Seth Meyers
and
John Oliver
will take part in the podcast that debuts on Wednesday called Strike Force Five.
Members of the
Writers Guild of America
went on strike in May and the
SAG-AFTRA
actors union walked off the job in July.
Without teams of writers to pen topical jokes, the late-night shows have been airing re-runs for nearly four months.

image.altText: South Coast bushfires in January 2020 captured from space.

items.synopsis: After the Black Summer fires, experts called for a way of detecting bushfires more rapidly, using satellites. But executing this idea faces challenges.

title.children: An audacious plan to rapidly detect bushfires from space appears to have hit a roadblock

image.altText: picture of a man holding a metal bucket sitting in a football stadium behind the goal post

items.synopsis: Alex Agelopoulos, who injured a goalkeeper with a bucket when Melbourne Victory fans violently stormed AAMI Park, was released on bail after his lawyer immediately appealed the three-month jail term he was handed.

title.children: 'Bucket man' handed jail sentence over violent pitch invasion at Melbourne A-League game

image.altText: A surgeon operates in a theatre.

items.synopsis: Only one in five general surgeons in Australia is a woman but that number falls to just 16 per cent outside the big cities, according to new research.

title.children: Why female surgeons are less likely to live outside the big cities

image.altText: You see a man in a bright neon yellow rain jacket in a field holding a bunch of overgrown weeds.

items.synopsis: Experienced forager Diego Bonetto says safe foraging comes down to careful identification of plants and vigilant hygiene practices.

title.children: Foragers highlight food safety after parasite likely ingested from foraged greens extracted from woman's brain

image.altText: Two Brisbane Lions AFL players prepare to run onto the field.

items.synopsis: From an initial squad off 44 players, 22 will earn the honour of being selected in the final All-Australian Team. Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson run the rule over who deserves to be in and who may miss out.

title.children: The AFL's All-Australian Team will be announced tonight. Who should make the cut?

image.altText: AI generated images of women from South Asia and East Asia

items.synopsis: AI-generated images of "beautiful" women from around the world have been going viral on TikTok. But some say they're based off stereotypes and can perpetuate colourist ideals.

title.children: Is there such thing as 'looking like' your ethnicity? These viral AI images think so

image.altText: Madison is holding a binder and smiling.

items.synopsis: As cost-of-living pressures continue to climb, people are looking for creative ways to save. One method gaining popularity on social media is called "cash stuffing". It's a reinvention of the old envelope system our grandparents used to use, and it's bringing back the use of physical cash.

title.children: Madison says she'll never use her card full-time again after discovering 'cash stuffing'

image.altText: An older woman with a dark grey bob and glasses speaks into a small microphone in front of a blue screen.

items.synopsis: Student protesters interrupt the beginning of a speech by incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock, taking issue with her past comment about needing to see the unemployment rate rise.

title.children: Protesters interrupt incoming RBA boss for wanting '140,000 people' to lose their jobs

image.altText: kelpie dog in a wheelchair in a grassy paddock

items.synopsis: The Australian kelpie lost the use of her hind legs in a farm accident six months ago, but thanks to a custom-made set of wheels, Ali is back at work doing what she loves.

title.children: Ali's new wheels a second chance to round up sheep, becoming a TikTok sensation along the way

image.altText: A white woman, a white man with down syndrome and another white man dance in loose fitting clothing on a stage.

items.synopsis: The 52-year-old choreographer and wheelchair user channelled her experience into an ode to vulnerability, which will open at Sydney Opera House this week before touring to Seoul.

title.children: Michelle transformed a distressing incident with the police into a world-class performance

image.altText: An elderly couple down a mall with the help of a younger woman.

items.synopsis: I've read the 300-odd pages of the Intergenerational Report pretty carefully and, with the exception of the section on climate change, I'm yet to find anything particularly alarming, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Australia isn't quite facing the 'ageing time bomb' alarmist headlines would have you believe

image.altText: A plane on a tar mac with a sunset backdrop

items.synopsis: Captain Eleanor V LeBeau, Corporal Spencer R Collart and Major Tobin J Lewis were killed in a military training exercise when their aircraft crashed and caught fire on Sunday.

title.children: Bodies of US marines killed in Tiwi Islands Osprey crash flown into Darwin

image.altText: A bin catching on fire in the back of a garbage truck

items.synopsis: The use of lithium battery-powered products in New South Wales is increasing, and so too is the rise in house fires caused by them.

title.children: Toxic fumes from lithium battery-ignited fires can be deadly. Here's what you should do

image.altText: Photo of Tracy Sorensen, who has brown eyes and is smiling to the camera with faded green background

items.synopsis: When author Tracy Sorensen realised she didn't know much about her body parts that were affected by cancer, she found a unique way to learn — and write — about them.

title.children: Author Tracy Sorensen was dealing with cancer. So she turned her spleen into an 'anarcho communist'

image.altText: An Australian cyclist grimaces and punches the air in jubilation after winning a stage in a sprint.

items.synopsis: Australia's Kaden Groves avoids some late crashes, loses his wingman but recovers to win the first sprint finish at this year's La Vuelta.

title.children: Australia's Kaden Groves wins La Vuelta stage four in sprint finish

image.altText: A close-up of a fire truck, with 'fire and rescue' written on red paint

items.synopsis: A 12-year-old boy is in custody after being found near the home by police.

title.children: Child charged with arson after allegedly starting blaze that destroyed Whitsundays home

image.altText: Wooden marionette and shadows.

items.synopsis: In the beginning, he was charming, gentle and caring — but after she and her two children moved in with him, everything changed. Coercive control was at the centre of their relationship — with a court in Hobart hearing from three other victims of the same man.

title.children: 'You used and abused these women as you pleased': Hugs in court as man jailed over repeated abuse

image.altText: Xavier Cooks dunking the basketball through a hoop.

items.synopsis: Australia's pursuit of men's basketball World Cup gold remains alive with Xavier Cooks dominating in the Boomers' 109-89 defeat of Japan.

title.children: Australia Cooks Japan for crucial World Cup win

image.altText: Several adult whales surrounded by numerous calves, as seen from above.

items.synopsis: A researcher says the reason for the decline is a mystery, but she hopes next year's survey reflects the results of a strong breeding season.

title.children: Southern right whale numbers have plunged on Australia's southern coast

image.altText: A couple pose in front of a brightly coloured wall with the national emblem of China, holding a bouqet of flowers between them

items.synopsis: A notice on Changshan county's official WeChat account, said the reward was to promote "age-appropriate marriage and child-bearing" for first marriages, the latest measure to incentivise young people to get married amid concern over a declining birth rate.

title.children: Chinese county offers 'cash reward' for couples if bride is 25 or under
